bcl:definition.bcl:text: diesel emission inspection means an inspection and test of a vehicle to determine whether or not the vehicle meets the diesel emission standards prescribed under the Heavy Vehicle Diesel Emission Standards Regulation, and includes a diesel emission reinspection;
diesel emission standards means the diesel emission standards prescribed under the Heavy Vehicle Diesel Emission Standards Regulation;
diesel engine means an engine that uses diesel fuel and in which internal combustion is initiated by compression instead of by a spark;
inspection facility means a facility designated by the director as an inspection facility under section 217 of the Act;
vehicle means a vehicle, powered by a diesel engine, with a licensed gross vehicle weight of more than 5 000 kg, but does not include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an implement of husbandry or a vehicle licensed under section 8, 9, 10 or 44 of the Act,
a road building machine as defined in the Commercial Transport Act, or
a vehicle of Her Majesty's Forces as defined in the National Defence Act (Canada).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Vehicles on highways must meet diesel emission standards
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated, a vehicle on a highway if the vehicle does not meet the diesel emission standards.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a peace officer believes on reasonable and probable grounds that a vehicle driven or operated on a highway does not meet the diesel emission standards, the peace officer may require the driver of the vehicle to stop for a diesel emission inspection of that vehicle.
The driver must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately come to a safe stop when signalled or requested by the peace officer to stop, and

in accordance with an order or direction of the peace officer, submit the vehicle to the diesel emission inspection and comply with any other orders or vehicle operating directions given by the peace officer for the purposes of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The peace officer must, on completion of the diesel emission inspection, complete an inspection report and give a copy of that report to the driver of the vehicle inspected.
If the vehicle fails the diesel emission inspection, the peace officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must notify the driver or owner of the failure, and
may order the driver or owner to present the vehicle to an inspection facility for reinspection within the period set out in the notification.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must comply with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the orders and directions given by a peace officer under subsection (2), and
an order referred to in subsection (4) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who contravenes section 40A.02 or 40A.03 (5) (a) commits an offence.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Heavy Vehicle Diesel Emission Control Device

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: diesel engine means an engine that uses diesel fuel and in which internal combustion is initiated by compression instead of by a spark;
inspection means an inspection and test of a vehicle to determine whether the vehicle is fitted with an emission control device;

vehicle means a commercial vehicle that is registered and licensed under section 6 of the Commercial Transport Act, powered by a diesel engine and with a licensed gross vehicle weight of more than 8 200 kg, but does not include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bus,
an emergency vehicle,
a vehicle

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that is an industrial machine or road building machine, other than a vehicle described by body style in Schedule 1 to Division 25 that has a licensed gross vehicle weight greater than 17 300 kg,
licensed under section 8, 9, 10, 38, 41, 42 or 44 of the Act,
owned by Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada,
driven under a permit issued under section 6 (7) of the Commercial Transport Act or under Division 14 of this regulation,
to which section 21 of the Act applies,
that is a commercial vehicle having a licensed gross vehicle weight of 17 300 kg or less and that is licensed and insured as a farm vehicle, or
that is exempted by the director under section 25.01 (3) or (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of inspection of a vehicle that is required under this Division to be equipped with an emission control device, Division 25, except section 25.01 (2) to (4), applies to the inspection and the vehicle as if the definition of "standards" in section 25.01 (1) included the requirements of section 40B.02.
A vehicle

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of a model year of 1989 to 1993 that has a diesel engine with a model year of 1989 to 1993, or
that has a diesel engine with a model year of 1989 to 1993

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be equipped with an emission control device that complies with subsection (3).
The model year of a vehicle's engine must be determined as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the year indicated on the engine information label;
if there is no label as described in paragraph (a), by the year of the chassis as indicated on the manufacturer's statement of compliance label.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An emission control device for a vehicle must reduce particulate matter emissions by at least 20%.
The director may exempt a vehicle from the requirement in section 40B.02 unconditionally or on conditions the director considers desirable, if one or more of the following circumstances exist:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the director is satisfied, based on information provided to the director, that an emission control device

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is not available for the diesel engine type or model year of that vehicle, or
cannot be installed on the vehicle for technical reasons;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use of the vehicle is required in an emergency.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For safety purposes, the director may exempt a vehicle from the requirement in section 40B.02 unconditionally or on conditions the director considers desirable.

The certificate set out in Schedule W is prescribed for the purposes of section 83.2 (2) (b) [traffic control signal] of the Act for use in relation to section 129 (1) [red light] of the Act.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: blood delivery vehicle means a motor vehicle that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: owned or operated by or on behalf of the Canadian Blood Services,
clearly marked as a Canadian Blood Services vehicle, and
used to transport blood or blood products;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cycle means cycle as defined in section 119 of the Act;
electric motor vehicle means a motor vehicle that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has an electric propulsion engine and a battery storage system that can be charged from an external electric charging outlet, and
displays a permit, in a form issued by the minister responsible for the administration of the Transportation Act, on the vehicle's rear bumper or rear window;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: handy dart vehicle means a vehicle designed to transport persons with disabilities and operated by a person in the business of providing transportation services to the public;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bus, or
a vehicle under 5 500 kg GVW that is carrying at least the minimum number of persons specified by the applicable traffic control device;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: high occupancy vehicle lane means a high occupancy vehicle lane as defined in section 119 of the Act;

marked vehicle means a vehicle that is referred to in section 4.28 (1) as authorized to be equipped with lamps that are capable of displaying flashes of light but does not include vehicles referred to in sections 4.28 (4), (5) (b) and (d), (6), 4.29 or 4.30;
officer means a person who is an agent for traffic direction purposes of the ministry or of the municipality in which the person is directing traffic or who is a peace officer;
traffic control device means a traffic control device as defined in section 119 of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rules for use of high occupancy lanes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not stop or park a vehicle or cycle in a high occupancy vehicle lane except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to comply with a traffic control device,
to comply with the instructions given by an officer,
the driver of a bus in a designated bus stop, or
the driver of the following vehicles while attending to a disabled vehicle or an emergency:

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A driver of a vehicle that is not a high occupancy vehicle must not use a high occupancy vehicle lane except if necessary

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to make a right turn from the lane, at the first intersection where the turn is permitted, to access a highway intersecting the lane or premises adjacent to the lane,
to make a right turn from an intersecting highway or premises adjacent to the lane, at the first intersection where the turn is permitted, to access the highway in which the lane is situated, or
to merge into an adjacent lane for the purposes of paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the driver of a marked vehicle responding to a disabled vehicle or another emergency on the highway where the high occupancy vehicle lane is located,
the driver of an emergency vehicle,
a peace officer on active duty,
an operator of a cycle, motorcycle, taxi, handy dart vehicle or an electric motor vehicle, or
the driver of a blood delivery vehicle while transporting blood or blood products.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (3) (d), subsection (2) applies to an operator of a cycle, motorcycle, taxi, handy dart vehicle or an electric motor vehicle if a traffic control device specifies that the operator is not to use the high occupancy vehicle lane except as specified in subsection (2).
